misconceptions.name: Solving a different problem (average acceleration) instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones, indicating a misunderstanding or disregard of the problem specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: I need to read v0, v1, and t and compute the average acceleration ( (v1 - v0) / t ), then print it.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers, check which of them are even, accumulate the sum of only those even integers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Computation uses the formula (v1 - v0) / t instead of summing selected inputs.
Output message describes 'The average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different textbook exercises or reusing code from another problem without adapting it to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and restate it in your own words. Then design variables, input, and a formula that match the required behavior (sum of even numbers) before you start coding.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt, variable names, formula, and output text) matches a standard 'average acceleration' exercise and does not mention sums or even numbers at all.

evidence.note: The prompt, computation, and output all correspond to an average-acceleration problem, not to summing even numbers from 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Reading only three values instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading 5 integers as required, the program reads only three numeric inputs (v0, v1, and t), so it cannot possibly process 5 numbers or compute the sum over those 5 values.
misconceptions.student_belief: I only need to read three numeric inputs from the user for this program.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read exactly 5 separate integers from the user (e.g., in a loop or as five separate reads) so that all five numbers can be checked and used in the sum.
symptoms: Only three calls to Scanner input methods.
No mechanism (loop or repeated statements) to obtain five separate numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the requirement on how many values to read, or copying from a different problem that used three inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Plan your input first: list how many values you need and their types. Then ensure your code has matching read operations (5 in this case), often best handled with a loop.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly reads only three values (v0, v1, t) and there is no other input logic present.

evidence.note: Only three numeric inputs are read, contradicting the requirement to read 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Using double instead of int for integer-style input
misconceptions.description: The student uses double variables and nextDouble() for values that, according to the problem, should be integers, suggesting a lack of attention to or understanding of the required data type.
misconceptions.student_belief: It's fine or preferable to store numeric keyboard input in double variables and read it with nextDouble(), even when the problem states integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When a problem specifies integers, you should generally use int variables and nextInt() (or equivalent) so that the types match the specification and to avoid unnecessary floating-point behavior.
symptoms: All numeric variables are declared as double.
Scanner uses nextDouble() instead of nextInt() for these inputs.
misconceptions.root_cause: A tendency to default to double for all numeric input, or not yet distinguishing clearly between integer and floating-point types.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review when to use int versus double. For counts or whole-number values, prefer int and read with nextInt(); reserve double for real numbers that may have fractional parts.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The variables are explicitly declared as double and read with nextDouble() in a context where the specification calls for integers.

evidence.note: Numeric inputs are stored in double variables and read with nextDouble(), whereas the task specifies integer inputs.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type for Integer Input
misconceptions.description: The student used `double` for input variables and `s.nextDouble()` to read input, whereas the problem explicitly requires reading integers (`int`).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student might believe that `double` is an appropriate type for any numerical input, even integers, or they simply followed the requirements of the wrong problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Integers should typically be read using `s.nextInt()` and stored in variables of type `int` to ensure whole-number arithmetic and correctness, especially when performing modulus operations (like checking for evenness).
symptoms: `double` keyword used for inputs
`s.nextDouble()` method used
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding when to use floating-point types vs. integer types, or adherence to the requirements of the wrong non-integer-based problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: When the problem specifies 'integers,' you must use the `int` data type and the `nextInt()` method of the Scanner class.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to handle multiple inputs

misconceptions.name: Missing even-number filtering logic
